{"uri": "2024-05-348338899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "00:22:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T00:22:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T13:40:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/prince-harry-makes-first-appearance-134050616.html", "title": "Prince Harry Makes First Appearance of U.K. Visit to Celebrate Invictus Games Anniversary", "body": "The Duke of Sussex is looking back at a decade of the adaptive sports tournament he founded for service personnel and veterans\n\nPrince Harry is taking the mic to support the Invictus Games.\n\nOn May 7, the Duke of Sussex, 39, joined a panel during his trip to the U.K. for the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games. The discussion, \"The IGF Conversation: Realizing a Global Community,\" is set to reflect on the global community of service personnel and their families that the Invictus Games has fostered since its inception a decade ago through the power of adaptive sport, from Prince Harry's initial inspiration at the Warrior Games to Invictus' impact in the years since.\n\nPrince Harry, a former captain in the British Army who served two tours in Afghanistan, launched the adaptive sports tournament for service personnel and veterans in 2014. The inaugural Invictus Games were held in London that September, and he traveled to the U.K. from his California home to celebrate the milestone anniversary.\n\nReflecting on the past decade of the Invictus Games, the Duke of Sussex was asked if there was a \"magic moment\" from the event that made him \"smile.\"\n\n\"It probably hasn't changed, still, it has to be in the beginning, 2014, in the copper box,\" he replied. \"I was at the DJ decks, trying to choose some of the music and put the lights on and just get people on their feet.\"\n\nPrince Harry shouted out Guy Monson, who \"never left his seat\" at the event.\n\n\"But it was that final game of U.S.A. vs. U.K., and it was just end to end. I think it was wheelchair rugby and wheelchair basketball. And that, to me, was the highlight because you had 6,000 people who had filled this stadium and were on their feet, every age from 95 to 5, and people were just literally blown away by what they were watching. We had no idea what was going to happen.\"\n\nHarry added, \"I think we've just had a huge amount of fun. I think that I personally have learned so much from the people that I have met. The children, the family, the friends, the individuals themselves, and the amount of respect and admiration I have for all of them just continues to build just year after year after year. And now we have these Invictus One Year to Go events as well because, to be honest with you, we can't wait two years!\"\n\n\"So whoever is going to host the next Games, we're all going to be there one year ahead, and then at the Games themselves,\" he continued. \"So the highlight for me is being in this community with all these people.\"\n\nCan't get enough of PEOPLE's Royals coverage? Sign up for our free Royals newsletter to get the latest updates on Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle and more!\n\nRelated: Prince Harry's Invictus Games Announce Finalists for 2027 Host City -- Including One in the U.S.\n\nBeyond the panel discussion, Harry's itinerary includes a service at St. Paul's Cathedral on May 8. The Duke of Sussex is set to deliver a reading at the cathedral in the heart of London, and Homeland star Damian Lewis will recite the poem \"Invictus.\" The prose by William Ernest Henley is full of meaning for the Invictus Games community, and the competition's motto \"I am\" comes from its final line -- \"I am the master of my fate, I am the captain of my soul.\"\n\nHenley is coincidentally commemorated with a memorial bust in the Crypt of St. Paul's, which is where the future King Charles and Princess Diana married in 1981.\n\nThe program is expected to bring together representatives from the Invictus Games' participating nations, including members of the wounded, injured and sick service personnel and veteran community. Invictus community members, supporters, and beneficiaries will also give readings and participate in the service, which will be led by The Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, Dean of St Paul's.\n\nNews of Prince Harry's Invictus-focused trip was announced on April 28 and brings him back to the U.K. for the first time in a few months. The Duke of Sussex flew to London in February for a private visit with his father, King Charles, after Buckingham Palace announced the sovereign's cancer diagnosis on Feb. 5. Several days later, he stepped out in Canada with his wife, Meghan Markle, Invictus Games Vancouver Whistler 2025's One Year to Go celebrations, which counted down to the seventh cycle of the games in Canada next year.\n\nRelated: Meghan Markle Won't Join Prince Harry in the U.K. Next Month Before Heading to Nigeria Together\n\nPrince Harry will not meet with King Charles during his trip to the U.K. for the Invictus Games anniversary, PEOPLE confirms.\n\nA spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex says, \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program. The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nRelated: How Meghan Markle and Prince Harry Are Celebrating Son Prince Archie's 5th Birthday\n\nPrince Harry made his latest visit to the U.K. solo, but he is due to reunite with Meghan, 42, for another significant trip this week. On the heels of the announcement of the Invictus anniversary plans, PEOPLE confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are heading to Nigeria. The couple accepted an invitation on behalf of the Chief of Defense Staff, the country's highest-ranking military official.\n\nDuring their visit, Prince Harry and Meghan will meet with service members and participate in a variety of cultural activities.\n\nThe agenda will highlight the Invictus Games following Nigeria's event debut at the latest Invictus Games in D\u00fcsseldorf, Germany in September 2023. Nigerian Minister of Defense Alhaji Mohammed Abubakar Badaru also attended the competition in Germany and has expressed interest in hosting the games in the future.\n\nPrince Harry and Meghan spent time with the Nigerian team at the tournament in D\u00fcsseldorf, and the Duke of Sussex revealed in his speech at the opening ceremony in Germany that his wife was rooting for the squad after discovering that she has Nigerian heritage, a revelation made on her Archetypes podcast in 2022.\n\n\"Now, I'm not saying we play favorites in our home, but since my wife discovered she's of Nigerian descent, it's likely to get a little bit more competitive this year,\" he joked.\n\nOn the topic of friendly allegiances and lighthearted rivalries, Prince Harry previously told PEOPLE that there was \"no picking sides\" for him between the U.K. and U.S. teams following his California move.\n\n\"I feel like I have a special bond with all the teams, and I'm very much a supporter of the sport, as opposed to the winning. So there's no picking sides for me!\" he told PEOPLE in 2022.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "janine_henni@yahoo.com", "name": "Janine Prince Harry will not be seeing his father King Charles during his current visit to Britain as the monarch will be too busy, Harry's spokesperson said on Tuesday.\n\nHarry, 39, has returned to Britain to attend a number of events to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, the international sporting event that he founded for military personnel wounded in action.\n\nThe younger son of King Charles has only been back in Britain on a few occasions since he and his American wife Meghan stepped down from official royal roles in 2020 and moved to Los Angeles where they live with their two young children.\n\nThey have since become estranged from the rest of the royal family and Harry is said to be barely on speaking terms with his elder brother, heir to the throne Prince William.\n\nHarry's last publicised trip came in February when he made a flying visit to see his father for a quick reunion after Buckingham Palace revealed that the 75-year-old king had been diagnosed with cancer.\n\nThere had been press speculation that the pair would meet up again on his latest trip, but a spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex said this would not happen.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme,\" the spokesperson said.\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nCharles returned to public duties last week for the first time since his diagnosis for an unspecified form of cancer. Buckingham Palace said the king's diary would be carefully managed to minimise any risks to his health.\n\nThe palace has said it would not comment on matters relating to Harry.\n\nOn Tuesday, Harry, who served in the British armed forces in Afghanistan, attended a number of appointments linked to the Invictus Games. On Wednesday he will appear at a service of thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral in London where he will deliver one of the readings.\n\nAfter leaving Britain, Harry will be joined by his wife Meghan {"uri": "8117041658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "09:15:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T09:15:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:14:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13395071/Raised-eyebrows-amid-King-Charles-make-William-Colonel.html", "title": "Raised eyebrows amid King Charles will make William Colonel", "body": "King Charles' timing raised a few eyebrows yesterday after he dealt two blows to Prince Harry within a matter of hours. Last night, Buckingham Palace announced that Prince William and his father would be attending a joint engagement next week, where the heir will be made the Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps.\n\nPrior to Prince Harry's decision to step back from royal life four years ago, it was always thought he would take on the role that would see him take charge of the regiment he was toured Afghanistan with until 2014. The announcement that the King would pass on the role he held for 31 years to his eldest son came just two hours after he said he was too busy to see his youngest son. 'Timing is everything,' one royal insider said, while another said the monarch's decision not to see the Duke of Sussex during whistle stop visit to the UK - despite only being three miles apart - 'will be widely perceived as a snub'.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex flew into London from California yesterday as he marks the tenth anniversary of his Invictus Games yet due to the King's busy schedule was unable to meet his father. Harry's spokesperson confirmed that it was 'unfortunately not possible' for the pair to meet 'due to His Majesty's full programme', as he returns to public duties after undergoing treatment for cancer . Following much speculation over whether the Duke would pop in to visit his father, who he last saw in February following his shocking diagnosis, Harry's spokesperson confirmed there was no time for a reunion.\n\n'In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme,' he said. 'The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.' Harry had been at the Honourable Artillery Company in London appearing on a stage during a discussion called Realising Global Community. His father was just down the road at Clarence House before holding an audience at nearby Buckingham Palace with the Prime Minister of Fiji, Sitiveni Rabuka.\n\nInstead of catching up with his estranged father, the Duke enjoyed dinner with city financier Guy Monson (pictured left) last night. 'This, whatever the logistics, will be widely perceived as a snub,' royal expert Richard Fitzwilliams told MailOnline. 'This is one of the most public rifts in the world. If it was handled in private without so much press speculation, it would have a better chance of being resolved.' Echoing the same sentiment, former BBC Royal correspondent Michael Cole added: 'It is quite a snub. For the King to not see his younger son, Prince Harry, although the two men will be only two miles apart tomorrow afternoon, gives an indication of the depth of the divide.\n\n'The Prodigal Son is not welcome - not for the present, anyway. In royal terms, this is big medicine. Prince Harry is bound to see it for what it is, the clearest possible indication of the hurt that has been caused. There can be no mistake: this is a royal flea in the ear for the fifth in line to the throne. Actions have consequences but rarely are they played out as starkly as they are here. 'Even Prince Harry, never the sharpest sword in the Household Cavalry, is bound to have got the message and many people will say, ''About time too''.'\n\nJust two hours after the revelation that Charles and Harry would not meet Buckingham Palace announced Prince William's new role. A statement read: 'At the Army Aviation Centre in Middle Wallop, His Majesty The King will officially hand over the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to His Royal Highness The Prince of Wales. 'In August 2023, following His Majesty's Accession, The King was pleased to announce military appointments including that The Prince of Wales would become Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps. 'The role was previously held by His Majesty The King, as Prince of Wales, for 31 years.'\n\nDuring the ceremony, Prince William will receive a briefing from the Colonel Commandant Lt-Gen Sir Nicholar Borton before viewing a training session. William, who flew for the Air Ambulance, will also take to the skies, controlling the the Apache for a flight. Today Prince Harry will give a reading at a service of thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral - marking a decade since the inaugural competition in London in 2014. Organisers had said there was no confirmation of any other royals attending, or if Harry's wife Meghan Markle or children Archie and Lilibet would also be in the UK.\n\nBut Harry arrived in London by himself today, and is expected to join the Duchess on a tour to Nigeria later this week with Meghan set to fly there from the US by herself. And Harry is not anticipated to see his brother Prince William, who is scheduled to be away from the capital on Thursday and Friday, or his sister-in-law Kate Middleton whose cancer treatment continues following her revealing the diagnosis in March.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? The prince previously returned to his home country back in February after learning of his father's cancer diagnosis. Now, Harry is heading back for an Invictus Games ceremony at St. Paul's Cathedral, though Meghan Markle will not be joining him. Despite that people were hoping the duchess would attend, it does at least give Harry a chance to spend time with King Charles -- if the king has time to see him, that is.\n\nHarry and Charles haven't seen each other in several months, but Harry did say back in February that he is \"grateful\" for the time he gets with his family and that he loves them. Tensions were quite high between Harry and Charles when Harry left the royal family back in 2020, but things have become more peaceful now between the men. Still, Charles reportedly had four words for the prince when Harry asked about meeting up with his father this week.\n\nAccording to Express, a source close to the king said that Charles said he will only meet up with Harry \"if he is able\" -- those four words suggest that it's not a top priority for the king. Harry did fly hours across the Atlantic back in February to see his father, so it's hard to imagine Charles wouldn't make the time for him. However, it remains unknown whether the two men will actually sit down and hash things out.\n\nPerhaps there is no reason to has things out -- at this point, we don't know what Charles and Harry talk about when they do communicate, and it's possible they respect each other's differences and spend time together to simply catch up and keep a relationship. For all we know, their \"peace talks\" might be a thing of the past.\n\nAlthough it seems likely that Harry will sit down with Charles, it's hard to know if the same can be said for Harry and William. Tensions seem to have only risen since Harry removed himself from the royal family, though it's hard to say what goes on behind closed doors.\n\nAs of right now, it seems unlikely that Harry and William will get together. {"uri": "8116765898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "06:14:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T06:14:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:13:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13386561/Invictus-Games-Prince-Harry-ten-years.html", "title": "Ten years of Prince Harry's Invictus Games", "body": "With Prince Harry currently on a lightning visit to the UK to mark 10 years of the Invictus Games, he will likely be feeling pride in what is his greatest achievement.\n\nYesterday the Duke, who has travelled without his wife Meghan Markle, attended a special service at St Paul's Cathedral to mark the milestone.\n\nThe event will have been especially meaningful for Harry, who founded the Invictus Games - the international sporting event for wounded servicemen and women - in 2014.\n\nThe Prince, who served two tours of Afghanistan as a soldier, previously said: 'I have witnessed first-hand how the power of sport can positively impact the lives of wounded, injured Servicemen and women in their journey of recovery.'\n\nBelow, we look back at 10 years of Invictus - from his laughter with William and Charles at the inaugural event in 2014 to one of his and Meghan's first appearances in 2017...and that famous 'boom' moment with his late grandmother the Queen.\n\n2014 - Inaugural games in London\n\nHarry, his brother Prince William and their father King Charles were in great spirits when the trio attended the inaugural games in London in September 2014.\n\nThey were snapped laughing as William showed his brother and father something on his smartphone.\n\nMeghan had yet to enter the picture, and Harry was newly single following his split four months earlier from Cressida Bonas.\n\nHarry, William and Charles were in great spirits when they attended the very first games in London in September 2014\n\nPrince Harry laughs as he plays volleyball with wounded service personnel at the launch of the Invictus Games at the Copper Box in the Olympic Park, East London\n\nPrince Harry plays sitting volleyball during the launch of the Invictus Games at the Copper Box Arena in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park\n\nHarry sits with his father Prince Charles, stepmother Camilla and brother Prince William during the opening ceremony for the first Invictus Games in 2014\n\nPrince Harry talks with wheelchair basketball players during the launch of the Invictus Games at the Copper Box Arena in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park on March 6, 2014\n\nOver the course of the four-day event, 14 countries competed in 10 disciplines and Harry was there for it all, happy and sporting a full head of hair.\n\nHe rolled around the floor laughing as he played volleyball and met invited Boris Johnson, then the Mayor of London, to watch a game of wheelchair rugby.\n\nMy mate Michelle (part one)\n\nIn October 2015 Prince Harry was joined by then first Lady Michelle Obama at an event in Virginia, USA to announce that the next Invictus Games would take part in Florida.\n\nPrince Harry greets first lady Michelle Obama as he takes the podium to speak after meeting with wounded servicemen and veterans at Fort Belvoir military base in Virginia, 2015\n\nFirst lady Michelle Obama, accompanied by Jill Biden, left, reacts as Prince Harry hands her the basketball at the conclusion of a game of wheelchair basketball by wounded servicemen\n\nStill young, free and single, Harry attended a wheelchair basketball game.\n\nBefore kicking the game off, Michelle announced to the crowd: 'Ok ladies, Prince Harry is here - don't act like you don't notice!'\n\nShe added said she would like to 'apologise for all the gold medals the USA will win,' prompting Harry to say: 'You better bring it USA!'\n\nGranny gets in on the act - April 2016\n\nHaving shown what a great sport she was at the London 2012 Olympics, with her James Bond sketch, Harry roped the late Queen into helping him promote the upcoming games in Orlando.\n\nThe Queen was brilliant in the sketch and when the Obama's reminded Prince Harry that he told the USA to 'bring it' she replied 'Oh really, please!\n\nAfter the late Queen's success at the London 2012 Olympics, Harry managed to persuade his grandmother to join him in the Invictus sketch in 2016 where he made a 'drop the mic' motion and said 'boom'\n\nShowing his grandmother a brochure of the games, his phone pinged with a video message from President Obama and First Lady Michelle.\n\nIt reminded Harry that he'd told the USA to 'bring it' and to 'be careful what you wish for.'\n\n'Oh really, please!' laughed Her Majesty as Harry made a 'drop the mic' motion and said 'boom' into the camera.\n\nCanada beckons\n\nBefore heading off to the Orlando games, in May 2016 Harry made a flying visit to Toronto to reveal that the Canadian city would be hosting the 2018 games.\n\nPrince Harry teamed up with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to announce the official countdown for Toronto 2017\n\nHe teamed up with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to announce the official countdown, not yet knowing just how much time he was about to be spending in that part of the world!\n\nMy mate Michelle (part 2)\n\nIn May 2016, Michelle Obama joined Harry for the opening ceremony of the Games in Orlando.\n\nBoth paid tribute to one another in their speeches.\n\nPrince Harry and Michelle Obama cheer during the opening ceremony of the Invictus Games in Orlando in 2016\n\nPrince Harry cheers during the wheelchair rugby competition at the Invictus Games, Orlando\n\nWhen the President was the vice President: Joe biden sharing a joke with Prince Harry\n\nThe day before the opening ceremony they gave a joint television interview, where Michelle revealed what a close relationship Harry had with his nephew Prince George, then two years old.\n\nToronto - a new games, and a new girlfriend\n\nThe Invictus games took place in Toronto in September 2017.\n\nThen First Lady Melania Trump attended the opening ceremony but - as glamorous as Melania was - there was only one woman everyone was interested in.\n\nBy then, Harry had been dating his new girlfriend, American actress Meghan Markle, for 10 months.\n\nPrince Harry met Melania Trump on the first day of the Invictus Games in September 2017\n\nHarry and his new girlfriend, the then Suits star Meghan Markle, watch wheelchair tennis on day three of the Invictus Games in Toronto, 2017\n\nPrince Harry being driven in a mini Land Rover on day one of the Invictus Games Toronto, 2017\n\nMeghan was living in Toronto - where her show Suits was filmed - and attended the opening ceremony with her mother Doria.\n\nLater, Meghan wore ripped jeans and a white 'husband' shirt by her friend Misha Nonoo while watching wheelchair tennis with Harry as the world got its first proper glimpse of a future Duchess.\n\nMeet the future missus\n\nIn April 2018, weeks before their wedding at St George's Chapel, Windsor, Harry took his future wife to the University of Bath's sports training village to meet the athletes hoping to represent the UK at the Sydney Games later that year.\n\nWeeks before the big wedding, Meghan joined Prince Harry as he met athletes hoping to represent the UK at the Sydney games later that year\n\nSydney - newlywed with a baby on the way\n\nIn October 2018, Harry and Meghan - now the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, announced they were expecting their first child.\n\nMeghan was in the early stages of pregnancy when she and Harry undertook a tour of Australia and New Zealand and were able to twin official duties with their attendance the games.\n\nMeghan and Harry attending the Invictus Games in Sydney in 2018. By then, Meghan was pregnant with the couple's first child\n\nMeghan presented medals to the winners of the wheelchair basketball final at the Quay Centre\n\nWhen Meghan stood up to make a speech during the closing ceremony, it became clear it was no longer all about Harry\n\nMeghan's fashion style took centre stage, as she wore an elegant navy Stella McCartney dress at the opening ceremony.\n\nBy the time the last event came around, it was clear the Invictus Games was no longer going to be all about Harry.\n\nOn the final day Meghan - wearing an olive-green tuxedo dress - took to the stage of the closing ceremony and gave a speech announcing how happy she was to join the 'Invictus family.'\n\nA Babygro for baby Archie\n\nJust three days after his son Archie arrived in May 2019, Harry travelled to The Hague to announce the countdown to the 2020 games, due to take part in the Netherlands.\n\nThree days after Archie was born Harry flew to the Hague and was presented with a babygro for his newborn son\n\nPrince Harry rides a bike around Sportcampus Zuiderpark as part of a programme of events to mark the official launch of the Invictus Games in The Hague\n\nBeaming with joy at being a new dad, Harry was delighted to be gifted a Babygro for his son by Princess Margriet of the Netherlands.\n\nMeeting the athletes in 2019\n\nIn October 2019, Harry met the 65 servicemen and women who would be representing the UK at the 2020 games in the Hague.\n\nPrince Harry met the 65 servicemen and women who were representing the UK at the next games in The Hague\n\nDays earlier, Meghan had told ITV's Tom Bradby in documentary Harry & Meghan an African journey that she had been struggling with royal life.\n\nThe couple then announced that they would shortly be taking a six-week break to spend time with their new son Archie.\n\nThe Hague - and how things have changed!\n\nFollowing two years of Covid cancellations, the Hague games finally took place in April 2022.\n\nAfter the coronavirus pandemic, the games took place again in 2022 and both Harry and Meghan were at the opening ceremony\n\nPrince Harry took part in the Jaguar Land Rover Driving Challenge in The Hague\n\nPrince Harry and Meghan attending the athletics event at The Hague in 2022\n\nA tense looking Harry watching an athletics event during the games in 2022\n\nPrince Harry was no longer a working royal when he attended the closing ceremony\n\nBy then Harry and Meghan - no longer working royals - had moved to Montecito and become parents for the second time to baby Lilibet, who was born in June 2021.\n\nFollowing their bombshell Oprah interview, Harry was estranged from his family.\n\nBut family feuds aside, he enjoyed a game of table tennis doubles and Meghan thrilled her fans with her stylish wardrobe.\n\nHad there been a medal for most extravagant outfits , she'd have won hands down!\n\nShe wore a \u00a32,400 boucle Celine jacket for the first day of the games and on day three displayed a total of \u00a38,600 worth of designer clothes, including a striking cream belted blazer by Brandon Maxwell.\n\nGet Ready Germany!\n\nIn September 2022 Harry and Meghan travelled to In August 2023, following His Majesty's Accession, The King was pleased to announce military appointments including that The Prince of Wales would become Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps. The role was previously held by His Majesty The King, as Prince of Wales, for 31 years.'\n\nThe announcement that the King would pass on the role he held for 31 years to his eldest son came just two hours after he said he was too busy to see his youngest son.\n\n'Timing is everything,' one royal insider said, while another said the monarch's decision not to see the Duke of Sussex during whistle stop visit to the UK - despite only being three miles apart - 'will be widely perceived as a snub'.\n\n'This, whatever the logistics, will be widely perceived as a snub,' royal expert Richard Fitzwilliams told MailOnline. Media close to the Sussexes had suggested he also 'fervently' wished to see his father while he was here.\n\nHarry has travelled alone, apart from his personal security guards, after claiming he does not feel safe bringing his family to the UK amid a continuing row with the Home Office following its decision to strip him of his round-the-clock Metropolitan Police protection when he left Britain.\n\nHe managed to fly into the country unobserved and his arrival came to light only when media favourable to the Sussexes were tipped off that he was attending a private panel discussion with TV presenter Louise Minchin at the Honourable Artillery Company.\n\nHe was said by sources to have had further sessions in the afternoon - including meeting business chief Sir Keith Mills, the former Invictus Games chairman - followed by a private dinner.\n\nIt has not been confirmed whether he came in on a scheduled, commercial flight, or flew by private jet from his home in California, or indeed where he is staying.\n\nHowever it is not believed to be in a royal residence. Harry has as no official home in the country after being asked to leave Frogmore, his and Meghan's Windsor home.\n\nHe is understood to have been staying in hotels or with friends during his occasional visits.\n\nAccording to reports, he plans to remain in the UK until tomorrow before flying to Nigeria where he will meet up with his wife for a quasi-royal tour, ostensibly to highlight the Invictus Games as well.\n\nThere are no plans for him to meet his estranged brother, Prince William, who is focusing on his wife, Catherine, Princess of Wales, who is herself undergoing preventative chemotherapy for cancer and is recovering from serious abdominal surgery in January. William is also due to undertake an investiture today and tomorrow will fly to Cornwall for further official engagements.\n\nHarry had not seen his father in person for 17 months before insisting he She also touched on how this all happened before Harry met Meghan.\n\n\"However, it was at these games that they first went public as a couple, making it an event close to Meghan's heart as well,\" Lynn added.\n\nShe then revealed the reason why she believes Meghan didn't come to the UK with her husband for the event, with Lynn telling The Mirror: \"Meghan likely didn't want to take the spotlight away from Harry on this important occasion, and she knew that her presence could attract all the attention and she knows there is some hostility towards her in the UK.\"\n\nWhen Harry landed in the UK on Tuesday, ITV's royal editor From Chris Ship confirmed: \"Prince Harry is in the UK. {"uri": "8116465437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:13:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:13:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:12:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/richard-kay-far-from-reuniting-them-charless-cancer-seems-to-have-added-to-their-estrangement/", "title": "RICHARD KAY: Far from reuniting them, Charles's cancer seems to have added to their estrangement", "body": "It is, of course, convenient to blame a busy schedule for \u00adeverything. And on the face of it, the King was very busy yesterday.\n\nFrom Windsor Castle where he had spent the Bank Holiday, he had an audience with Fiji's prime minister at Buckingham Palace, followed by a meeting with senior military commanders, and then medical appointments connected to his ongoing cancer treatment, the last of which are followed by an \u00adobligation to rest.\n\nToday promises more of the same, including a Palace garden party and his regular weekly sit down with PM Rishi Sunak, who after last week's drubbing for the Tories in the local elections may need more consoling than usual.\n\nWhat there most definitely was no time for amid all this coming and going, was any kind of get together with his younger son. Prince Harry's arrival in Britain had triggered speculation that father and son would meet.\n\nSome had even boldly suggested that such a meeting might, at long last, start a process of reconciliation between the King and Harry. Indeed, there was even murmur of an olive branch being extended.\n\nFar from Harry's hope of reuniting with his father in the wake of the King's cancer diagnosis, the illness has, if anything, added to their estrangement\n\nInstead, the hand-wringing excuses of 'full diaries' offers a different and, for Harry, a more ominous message. Unlike that dramatic flying visit in February, where the Prince was granted a less than 30-minute meeting just after Charles's cancer diagnosis had been made public, the palace gates remained firmly closed.\n\nPointedly, it was the Duke of Sussex's team that broke cover with a spokesman explaining that a meeting 'unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme'.\n\nEven with the acknowledgement that Harry recognised his father's 'commitments and various other priorities', the nuance in the bulletin was clear: the failure to meet was not Harry's fault. So much for olive branches.\n\nPrince Harry's arrival in Britain for The Invictus Games Foundation Conversation had triggered speculation that father and son would meet\n\nWhat then is going on, and what do events tell us about the state of relations between the exiled Harry, his father and the rest of the Royal Family?\n\nOne conclusion would suggest that, far from his hope of reuniting with his father in the wake of the King's cancer diagnosis, the illness has, if anything, added to their estrangement.\n\nBut, in fact, I understand that there had been no formal request from either the King or his son to schedule a meeting. For Harry also had a packed programme. From his overnight flight from Los Angeles, he was whisked to an event for the Invictus Games, his project for wounded and former armed forces personnel, at Armoury House in East London.\n\nAlthough little more then three miles from Buckingham Palace, he might as well have been on a different continent as far as meeting his family was concerned.\n\nCharles met with Fijian PM Sitiveni Rabuka yesterday while Harry arrived in the UK\n\nAnd today, while the King hosts the first garden party of the year, the Prince will mark the tenth anniversary of the games with a service at St Paul's cathedral. If Harry had been so set on seeing his father, it is tempting to wonder why he didn't fly over a day or two earlier when Charles had no official duties. How significant that might have been if they had been together on the first anniversary of the King's coronation. Inconveniently, that fell on Prince Archie's fifth birthday and Harry chose to spend it with his family in California.\n\nOnce, Harry's return visits to the UK meant it was relatively straightforward for him to drop in on his father, but he no longer has royal accommodation. And, intriguingly, he made no request to stay at any royal residence for this two-night visit.\n\nThis alone suggests that chances of a rapprochement are more remote than ever. Trust too has evaporated in the 16 months since Harry's explosive memoir Spare, with its excoriating attacks on Camilla, \u00adWilliam and Kate.\n\nHarry speaks onstage with Sir Keith Mills to mark ten years since the inaugural Invictus Games in London 2014\n\nThe two men once shared a special bond, but each meeting between them became distracted with the weight of \u00adprevious disappointments.\n\nSome old friends were surprised that given his Christian faith, a King who practises humility and empathy as a matter of course, could find no time to see his son. Others argued that no blame could surely be attached to Charles if he viewed such encounters with his son as more a burden than a pleasure.\n\nWhat is certain is that notwithstanding that busy workload, two figures would have viewed the prospect of a meeting between the King and Harry deeply troubling -- Queen Camilla, who was hurt by \u00adHarry's lacerating attacks, and Prince William who will not \u00adforgive his brother for his comments about Kate.\n\nLast month, the historian Tessa Dunlop suggested Harry was in a 'painful place' following the Princess of Wales's cancer diagnosis and William's remarks.\n\n'The opposition of Camilla and William would be formidable to Charles,' says a courtier. 'For all his affection for Harry -- which remains -- and sadness at the deep rift that has developed, his ties with his wife and older son are far deeper.'\n\nPerhaps the most telling observation on the broken relationship between Harry and the royals came in, not off-the-record briefings yesterday, but publication of a future joint engagement between the King and his son -- the other one.\n\nNext Monday, Charles will, amid a colourful ceremony, formally hand over the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to Prince William.\n\nHarry, of course, enjoyed a distinguished career with the combat aviation arm of the Army, serving with considerable bravery as a helicopter pilot in Afghanistan. This passing of the baton, however, speaks more eloquently of a united family. The Duke, of course, is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nCharles, who recently resumed royal duties amid his cancer treatment, hosted an audience at Buckingham Palace on May 7, receiving the Prime Minister of Fiji, Sitiveni Rabuka.\n\nAdditionally, the Palace is preparing to hold its first garden party of the season on May 8, though the attendees from the royal family remain undisclosed.\n\nWhen it was confirmed that the King and his son would not have a reunion during the Duke's stay in the UK, royal fans took to social media to voice their opinions.\n\nOne critic of the monarch expressed disappointment, stating, \"I always thought that people wanted to mend fences when their days were running short. I guess some people want to die estranged and miserable.\"\n\nAnother supporter praised Harry for his maturity, stating, \"Prince Harry is the ADULT in the Royal Family. He lets King Charles, a 75-year-old man, continue to play silly childish tabloid 'SNUB' games. Well done, Prince Harry. You are the TRUE KING of actual global [credentials] and respect.\"\n\nA third person noted, \"Given that the [Royal Family] is providing sanctuary for an alleged rapist, you'd think they would be utilizing the global popularity of H&M to improve their public image instead the self-destruction currently being played out in public.\"\n\nIn an attempt to defend the King's actions, one X user wrote: \"#KingCharles has deftly taken the wind out of his son's sails. The snub is strategic - Harry can't flounce off to Africa BLABBING his mouth off about meeting the King and updating his condition during ANY interviews in Africa. Well played, #KingCharlesIII.\"\n\nAnother individual noted, \"I wouldn't want to see my kid if he didn't like me. Sure, there's love there; they just don't like each other, and there's zero trust on Dad's side.\"\n\nThe royal \"snub\" coincided with a recent announcement by Buckingham Palace regarding military leadership.\n\nIn the statement released by the Palace, Charles will hand over Harry's position as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to his older brother, Prince William. The official handover ceremony is slated for May 13 at the Army Aviation Centre in Middle Wallop.\n\nThe Palace's statement reads: \"His Majesty The King will officially pass on the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to His Royal Highness The Prince of Wales.\"\n\nIt continued: \"In August 2023, following His Majesty's Accession, the King was pleased to announce military appointments including that the Prince of Wales would become Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps. The role was previously held by His Majesty the King, as Prince of Wales, for 31 years.\"\n\nIn reaction to the news of King Charles' snub, royal experts weighed in, with some noting that it shows how bad things have gotten between father and son.\n\nRichard Fitzwilliams said,\" 'This, whatever the logistics, will be widely perceived as a snub.\"\n\nHe suggested handling the situation privately, adding: \"This is one of the most public rifts in the world. If it was handled in private without so much press speculation, it would have a better chance of being resolved.\"\n\nMichael Cole echoed this sentiment, describing it as \"quite a snub.\" He continued: \"For the King to not see his younger son, Prince Harry, although the two men will be only two miles apart tomorrow afternoon, indicates the depth of the divide.\"\n\nCole described it as a \"royal flea in the ear for the fifth in line to the throne,\" adding: \"Even Prince Harry, never the sharpest sword in the Household Cavalry, is bound to have got the message and many people will say, \"About time too.\"\n\nWilliam and Kate have been at loggerheads with Harry and Meghan after they were left feeling \"betrayed\" by claims made in Harry's record-breaking memoir \"Spare.\"\n\nHowever, a source speaking to US Weekly revealed that the Prince and Princess of Wales want a \"truce\" and are \"open\" to reconciling with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.\n\nThe source explained that William and Kate are considering mending their broken relationship with Harry and his wife because of their children, as they don't want their feud to be passed on to the next When the games were founded in 2014, King Charles (when Prince of Wales), Prince William and Princess Kate all attended events in support.\n\nKing Charles was diagnosed with an undisclosed form of cancer in February 2024 and has been undergoing treatment since then.\n\nIn the hours after the announcement was made to the public on February 5, Harry traveled to Britain to visit his father. Instead of dressing to the nines on Monday, the pair celebrated son Archie's 5th birthday. (The couple also share daughter Lilibet, 2.)\n\nThe following day, Harry arrived in the U.K. to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games. Harry was photographed at The IGF Conversation: Realizing a Global Community event on Tuesday, May 7, and spotted alongside Dominic Reid OBE, CEO of the Invictus Games Foundation.\n\nMarkle and their two children are not expected to join the trip overseas, but the couple are set to travel to Nigeria following Harry's visit. While in the U.K., Harry is not expected to reunite with his father, King Charles III.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program,\" a spokesperson for Harry confirmed to The Post on Tuesday.\n\nPrior to the trip, a source exclusively told Us Weekly that it was unclear whether Harry would see any of his family members, including his brother, Prince William.\n\n\"The brothers haven't spoken [but] there is potential for that. [Harry] would be more than happy,\" the insider shared, noting that Harry invited his family to the Invictus Games.\n\nA separate source noted that Harry is \"very content\" now and \"doesn't have any of those [old] feelings\" regarding his family's ups and downs.\n\n\"He feels that his life has purpose and meaning and that he can bring a lot of good to the world,\" the second insider said.", {"uri": "8117206968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:54:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:54:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:53:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/king-charles-snub-prince-harry-error-apache-afghanistan-1898183", "title": "King Charles' snub for Prince Harry may be costly error", "body": "King Charles III appeared to twice snub Prince Harry on the first day of his youngest son's visit to Britain -- even as the duke shone a spotlight on the needs of veterans.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex is in London to mark the tenth anniversary of the Invictus Games, his tournament for wounded armed forces personnel, including through a Service of Thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral on Wednesday.\n\nHours after Harry arrived on Tuesday, his spokesperson confirmed he will not be able to meet the king due to Charles' schedule and \"other priorities.\"\n\nSpeculation had been building in the British media that father and son would see each other in what would have been a positive sign for their relationship and in a context where the king is still recovering from cancer.\n\nA spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program.\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nThere has been no official comment from the palace side to explain why Charles is not meeting Harry, leaving his motivation somewhat open to interpretation.\n\nHours after that revelation, though, Buckingham Palace announced a ceremony to give Prince William an accolade that would once have been destined for Harry.\n\nMultiple aspects of the engagement, due on Monday, appear -- whether intentionally or not -- tailor-made to rub Harry's nose in it.\n\nPrince William will be officially made colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corps, Prince Harry's former regiment, in which he served as co-pilot gunner of an Apache helicopter on the front line in Afghanistan between September 2012 and January 2013.\n\nThe appointment was announced last summer but the announcement of the ceremony itself and choreography on the day may sting for Harry not least because of the timing and the wide interpretation in the British media.\n\nEven the relatively sober Independent presented it as a \"snub\" and broadsheet The Times went with the headline: \"King favors William over Harry for air corps honor.\"\n\nThe king will unveil a plaque relating to an Apache AH Mk.1 that was in battle in Afghanistan in 2007, which is included in an exhibition at The Army Flying Museum.\n\nThat is the very same year that Harry began his first tour of Afghanistan, and Charles and William will go on to pose together in front of an Apache.\n\nA palace press release reads: \"Finally, The Prince [William] will depart the base by embarking on an Apache capability flight to deepen his understanding of the capabilities of the equipment and to learn more about the people that fly and support it.\"\n\nOf course, had Harry still been a working royal there would have been no need to \"deepen his understanding of the capabilities of the equipment\" as he was trained to operate the Apache in combat.\n\nCharles and William could, of course, defuse any potential offense caused if they were to commend Harry's service on the front line in Afghanistan during the engagement itself.\n\nRoyal fans will have to wait and see what happens but some may think it does not feel particularly likely given the fact Charles has not been able to meet Harry.\n\nOne major risk factor for the king and the palace, however, is the perception that they are in fact attacking Harry on his strongest subject -- his military career.\n\nHarry served on the front line in Afghanistan, whereas Charles and William did not, and has for ten years hosted a major, internationally respected tournament in support of veterans, which they do not.\n\nAnd, for all the hostility towards Harry, there remains respect in both Britain and America for his military work both as a soldier and an advocate.\n\nIn the run-up to Queen Elizabeth II's funeral, even committed Harry and Meghan Markle critic Piers Morgan defended Harry's right to wear his military uniform in support of his grandmother after he was initially denied the opportunity by the palace.\n\nThe symbolic messaging in relation to William's new role also serves as a reminder that honorary military titles can be given out to any royal family member irrespective of whether they have earned their stripes.\n\nAnd that risks making the business of monarchy look like an elaborate game of dress up. Graham Smith, chief executive of anti-Monarchy campaign group Republic, told Newsweek: \"It's all cosplay and it's all just trying to find ways to make themselves relevant and important.\n\n\"To my mind, and the minds of a lot of ex-services who we have among our members, it's completely inappropriate for them to be dressing up in medals and uniforms they haven't earned. They need to stop using the military as a play thing.\"\n\nTake, for example, Prince Edward who dropped out before ever completing basic training for the Royal Marines. No doubt he had his reasons, but as a working royal he is allowed to wear military uniform during royal events, including the queen's funeral, while Harry who served on the front line is not.\n\nThe reason is because he has been handed eight honorary military titles, including for example Royal Honorary Colonel of the Royal Wessex Yeomanry and The London Guards, because someone needs to hold those titles and he is a working royal.\n\nIn a context where Charles and William have already beaten Harry in the court of public opinion in Britain they are now at risk of exposing their underlying weakness and Harry's strength by picking the wrong battlefield.\n\nOn the other hand, if Charles and William are not taking a swipe at Harry then they could do with offering some kind of on-the-record explanation of why Charles is not meeting his son, and perhaps they might even consider recognizing the tenth anniversary of the Invictus Games which exists to support wounded veterans.\n\nThe British Government was represented at a conference marking ten years of the Invictus Games Foundation on Tuesday, where veterans minister Johnny Mercer was in attendance and he may well be back out at St Paul's Cathedral on Wednesday.\n\nYet the royal family so far have said nothing to support Harry's project, even though it was launched in 2014 while he was a working royal, and the king has found no time to meet his son.\n\nJack Royston is Newsweek's chief royal correspondent based in London. You can find him on X, formerly Twitter, at @jack_royston and read his stories on Newsweek's The Royals Facebook page.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, The discussion, \"The IGF Conversation: Realizing a Global Community\" is set to reflect on the global community of service personnel and their families that the Invictus Games has fostered since its inception a decade ago through the power of adaptive sport, from Prince Harry's initial inspiration at the Warrior Games to Invictus' impact in the years since.\n\nPrince Harry, a former captain in the British Army who served two tours in Afghanistan, launched the adaptive sports tournament for service personnel and veterans in 2014. The inaugural Invictus Games were held in London that September, and he traveled to the U.K. from his California home to celebrate the 10th anniversary.\n\nBeyond the panel discussion, the itinerary includes a service at St. Paul's Cathedral on May 8. The Duke of Sussex is set to deliver a reading at the cathedral in the heart of London, and Homeland star Damian Lewis will recite the poem \"Invictus.\" The prose by William Ernest Henley is full of meaning for the Invictus Games community, and the competition's motto \"I am\" comes from its final line -- \"I am the master of my fate, I am the captain of my soul.\"\n\nRelated: Prince Harry's Invictus Games Announce Finalists for 2027 Host City -- Including One in the U.S.\n\nHenley is coincidentally commemorated with a memorial bust in the Crypt of St. Paul's, which is where the future King Charles and Princess Diana married in 1981.\n\nThe program is expected to bring together representatives from the Invictus Games' participating nations, including members of the wounded, injured and sick service personnel and veteran community. Invictus community members, supporters, and beneficiaries will also give readings and participate in the service, which will be led by The Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, Dean of St Paul's.\n\nNews of Prince Harry's Invictus-focused trip was announced on April 28 and brings him back to the U.K. for the first time in a few months. The Duke of Sussex flew to London in February for a private visit with his father King Charles after Buckingham Palace announced the sovereign's cancer diagnosis on Feb. 5. Several days later, he stepped out in Canada with his wife Meghan Markle Invictus Games Vancouver Whistler 2025's One Year to Go celebrations, which counted down to the seventh cycle of the games in Canada next year.\n\nRelated: Meghan Markle Won't Join Prince Harry in the U.K. Next Month Before Heading to Nigeria Together\n\nPrince Harry will not meet with his father, King Charles, during his trip to the U.K. for the Invictus Games anniversary, PEOPLE confirms.\n\nA spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex says, \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program. The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nPrince Harry made his latest visit to the U.K. solo, but he is due to reunite with Meghan, 42, for another significant trip this week. On the heels of the announcement of the Invictus anniversary plans, PEOPLE confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are heading to Nigeria. The couple accepted an invitation on behalf of the Chief of Defense Staff, the country's highest-ranking military official.\n\nDuring their visit, Prince Harry and Meghan will meet with service members and participate in a variety of cultural activities.\n\nThe agenda will highlight the Invictus Games following Nigeria's event debut at the latest Invictus Games in D\u00fcsseldorf, Germany in September 2023. Nigerian Minister of Defense Alhaji Mohammed Abubakar Badaru also attended the competition in Germany and has expressed interest in hosting the games in the future.\n\nCan't get enough of PEOPLE's Royals coverage? Sign up for our free Royals newsletter to get the latest updates on Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle and more!\n\nPrince Harry and Meghan spent time with the Nigerian team at the tournament in D\u00fcsseldorf, and the Duke of Sussex revealed in his speech at the opening ceremony in Germany that his wife was rooting for the squad after discovering that she has Nigerian heritage, a revelation made on her Archetypes podcast in 2022.\n\n\"Now, I'm not saying we play favorites in our home, but since my wife discovered she's of Nigerian descent, it's likely to get a little bit more competitive this year,\" he joked.\n\nOn the topic of friendly allegiances and lighthearted rivalries, Prince Harry previously told PEOPLE that there was \"no picking sides\" for him between the U.K. and U.S. teams following his California move.\n\n\"I feel like I have a special bond with all the teams, and I'm very much a supporter of the sport, as opposed to the winning. {"uri": "8116603363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:55:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:55:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:55:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/prince-harry-uk-10-years-invictus-games-what-are-they-13768153.html", "title": "Prince Harry returns to UK to mark 10 years of Invictus Games:\u00c2 What are they?", "body": "Prince Harry speaks during the opening ceremony of the Invictus Games hosted in Toronto, Canada in September 2017. File Image/Reuters\n\nPrince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, arrived in the United Kingdom on Tuesday to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, the renowned biennial sporting competition he founded a decade ago. The celebration will take place with a ceremony at London's St. Paul's Cathedral on 8 May (Wednesday), where Harry will give a reading.\n\nThe Duke and his wife, Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, relocated to the United States in 2020. Since then, Harry, aged 39, has undertaken several brief visits back to the UK, notably attending the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II in 2022 and his father's coronation last year.\n\nHis latest visit was a brief one when he had rushed to see King Charles following his cancer diagnosis in February.\n\nMeghan, however did not accompany Harry to the UK. The ceremony will be Harry's first major event in the UK since his relocation to the US.\n\nWhat are the Invictus Games?\n\nThe Invictus Games, an international multi-sport event inaugurated in 2014, serves as a platform for wounded, injured, and sick servicemen and women, encompassing both current serving members and veterans. The term 'Invictus,' derived from Latin meaning 'unconquered,' was chosen deliberately to encapsulate the indomitable spirit of these individuals, showcasing what they can achieve post-injury.\n\nHarry, serving as patron of 'The Royal Foundation of The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry', alongside the UK Ministry of Defence and Keith Mills, then-deputy chairman of the London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, is credited with the founding of the Invictus Games.\n\nSpeaking at the launch in London on 6 March, 2014, Harry said that the Games would \"demonstrate the power of sport to inspire recovery, support rehabilitation and demonstrate life beyond disability\". Harry also averred that the long-term objective of the Games was to ensure that injured troops were not forgotten as Britain's involvement with the War in Afghanistan came to an end.\n\nThe Invictus Games, the games website says, are \u00e2\u20ac\u0153much more than just sport \u00e2\u20ac\" it captures hearts, challenges minds and changes lives\u00e2\u20ac.\n\nWhere did the idea for the Games come about?\n\nIn 2013, Harry's visit to the Warrior Games, a competition organised by the US Department of Defence for wounded servicemen, left a profound impact on him.\n\nHe openly acknowledged that he \"stole\" the idea, recognising the transformative potential of sports in aiding physical, psychological, and social well-being.\n\n\"He saw how the power of sport could help physically, psychologically and socially,\" reads the\u00c2 Invictus Games website. \"His mind was made up. London would host the inaugural Invictus Games, an international sporting event for wounded, injured and sick Service personnel.\"\n\nDetermined to translate this vision into reality, Harry spearheaded the initiative to host the inaugural Invictus Games in London, just one year later. Since then, he has remained actively involved, serving as the patron of the Invictus Games Foundation.\n\nWill the Royal Family join Prince Harry on 8 May?\n\nWhile Harry extended invitations to his family members for the ceremony, it's unlikely that any senior royals will attend due to various reasons, including health concerns. Kate Middleton and King Charles are both battling cancer.\n\nAlso Read: Prince Harry & Meghan Markle's net worth is nearly Rs 500 crore but where the couple stands in front of Prince William & Kate Middleton?\n\nHarry's accommodations during his visit will be in a hotel, as he no longer has a residence in the UK after vacating Frogmore Cottage. The presence of other royal family members, including Princess Beatrice, Princess Eugenie, and Zara Tindall, who are reportedly close to Prince Harry also remains uncertain.\n\nAre the Games still relevant?\n\nDespite the noble intentions behind the Invictus Games, recent reports suggest challenges and criticisms. Around 2,000 ex-servicemen have reportedly left the Games, claiming it has lost its original meaning.\n\nSome have raised concerns about the event becoming overly associated with royalty, while others have cited issues with Meghan Markle's involvement. However, doubts persist about whether Harry will heed such criticism, with suggestions that stepping down could lead to positive public relations outcomes.\n\nWhen are the next Games being held?\n\nWith six editions already gone, the upcoming edition of the Invictus Games is slated to take place in Vancouver and Whistler, Canada, scheduled from 8 February to 16, 2025. This marks the second occasion that Canada has been chosen as the host country for the games, following Toronto's successful hosting in 2017.\n\nWinter sports will debut at these games, further diversifying the range of adaptive sports offered. Moreover, discussions about the possibility of Nigeria hosting future Invictus Games are underway, as Harry and Meghan are set to visit the African nation later this month.\n\nAlso Read: All you need to know about Markle\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s Nigerian ancestry and her trip\n\nBids are actively being pursued for the honor of hosting the 2027 games, with Birmingham in England and Washington DC, both in contention. The decision regarding the successful host city is anticipated to be announced by July end this year.\n\nNational teams of athletes are sent from more than 20 countries, including the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, Denmark, Poland, Nigeria, Ukraine and Afghanistan.\n\n\"The Invictus Games Vancouver Whistler 2025 presented by ATCO and Boeing will bring together over 500 competitors from over 20 nations to compete in adaptive sports, including the new winter sports: Alpine Skiing and Snowboarding, Nordic Skiing and Biathlon, Skeleton, and Wheelchair Curling, in Prince Harry's arrival in Britain had triggered speculation that father and son would meet.\n\nSome had even boldly suggested that such a meeting might, at long last, start a process of reconciliation between the King and Harry. Indeed, there was even murmur of an olive branch being extended.\n\nFar from Harry's hope of reuniting with his father in the wake of the King's cancer diagnosis, the illness has, if anything, added to their estrangement\n\nInstead, the hand-wringing excuses of 'full diaries' offers a different and, for Harry, a more ominous message. Unlike that dramatic flying visit in February, where the Prince was granted a less than 30-minute meeting just after Charles's cancer diagnosis had been made public, the palace gates remained firmly closed.\n\nPointedly, it was the Duke of Sussex's team that broke cover with a spokesman explaining that a meeting 'unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme'.\n\nEven with the acknowledgement that Harry recognised his father's 'commitments and various other priorities', the nuance in the bulletin was clear: the failure to meet was not Harry's fault. So much for olive branches.\n\nPrince Harry's arrival in Britain for The Invictus Games Foundation Conversation had triggered speculation that father and son would meet\n\nWhat then is going on, and what do events tell us about the state of relations between the exiled Harry, his father and the rest of the Royal Family?\n\nOne conclusion would suggest that, far from his hope of reuniting with his father in the wake of the King's cancer diagnosis, the illness has, if anything, added to their estrangement.\n\nBut, in fact, I understand that there had been no formal request from either the King or his son to schedule a meeting. For Harry also had a packed programme. From his overnight flight from Los Angeles, he was whisked to an event for the Invictus Games, his project for wounded and former armed forces personnel, at Armoury House in East London.\n\nAlthough little more then three miles from Buckingham Palace, he might as well have been on a different continent as far as meeting his family was concerned.\n\nCharles met with Fijian PM Sitiveni Rabuka yesterday while Harry arrived in the UK\n\nAnd today, while the King hosts the first garden party of the year, the Prince will mark the tenth anniversary of the games with a service at St Paul's cathedral. If Harry had been so set on seeing his father, it is tempting to wonder why he didn't fly over a day or two earlier when Charles had no official duties. How significant that might have been if they had been together on the first anniversary of the King's coronation. Inconveniently, that fell on Prince Archie's fifth birthday and Harry chose to spend it with his family in California.\n\nOnce, Harry's return visits to the UK meant it was relatively straightforward for him to drop in on his father, but he no longer has royal accommodation. And, intriguingly, he made no request to stay at any royal residence for this two-night visit.\n\nThis alone suggests that chances of a rapprochement are more remote than ever. Trust too has evaporated in the 16 months since Harry's explosive memoir Spare, with its excoriating attacks on Camilla, \u00adWilliam and Kate.\n\nHarry speaks onstage with Sir Keith Mills to mark ten years since the inaugural Invictus Games in London 2014\n\nThe two men once shared a special bond, but each meeting between them became distracted with the weight of \u00adprevious disappointments.\n\nSome old friends were surprised that given his Christian faith, a King who practises humility and empathy as a matter of course, could find no time to see his son. Walking with a black folder under his arm, he nervously chuckled as he was asked if he was happy to be home. He dodges the question and says in response: 'Nice to see you.'\n\nIt comes after Harry admitted that his father King Charles was too busy to see him this week.\n\nAfter weeks of speculation about a reunion, his spokesman announced stiffly that a meeting 'will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme'.\n\nHarry tried to put a brave face on the situation, saying he understood his father's position and 'hopes to see him soon'. But the news will have come as a crushing blow to the prince, who told US television in February he hoped Charles's illness could 'reunify' the Royal Family.\n\nA smartly dressed smiling Prince Harry said hello and waved at onlookers as he walked with a black folder under his arm\n\nAsked if he was happy to be home he nervously chuckles and dodges the question as he mutters in response: 'Nice to see you'\n\nWhile Harry was just three miles - or a 25-minute drive away - on an engagement in east London yesterday, Charles met the prime minister of the Republic of Fiji at Buckingham Palace, before retiring to Clarence House.\n\nToday he again has meetings at Buckingham Palace in the morning before attending the first royal garden party of the season in the afternoon, followed by his weekly audience with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and a Privy Council meeting well into the evening.\n\nHis spokesman said: 'In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it, unfortunately, will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\n'The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.'\n\nRoyal aides have repeatedly declined to comment on anything to do with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex for fearing of triggering yet another war of words across the Atlantic.\n\nHowever, just hours after Harry's statement, palace officials blithely announced a new joint engagement for Charles and his eldest son William.\n\nIt is one of dozens of official engagements being planned for the 75-year-old monarch in the coming months after his doctors gave him the all-clear to undertake more public work once again while continuing his cancer treatment.\n\nKing Charles III leaving Windsor Castle yesterday\n\nPrince Harry at the Honourable Artillery Company in London yesterday\n\nTomorrow he is expected at an as-yet unannounced engagement outside London. It is not believed that Harry was encouraged to put out a statement himself because there is little in the way of communications between the palace and his people.\n\nBut it no doubt became clear the continued speculation about family relations would continue to overshadow the work he has come here to do.\n\nThe 39-year-old prince, who remains fifth in line to the throne despite quitting royal duties and the UK, is in London for several days for engagements centred around the Paralympic-style Invictus Games, which he founded in 2014 for injured service personnel.\n\nYesterday he attended an event to mark the legacy of the games and today will give a reading at a St Paul's Cathedral service to mark the event's tenth anniversary. Media close to the Sussexes had suggested he also 'fervently' wished to see his father while he was here.\n\nHarry has travelled alone, apart from his personal security guards, after claiming he does not feel safe bringing his family to the UK amid a continuing row with the Home Office following its decision to strip him of his round-the-clock Metropolitan Police protection when he left Britain.\n\nHe managed to fly into the country unobserved and his arrival came to light only when media favourable to the Sussexes were tipped off that he was attending a private panel discussion with TV presenter Louise Minchin at the Honourable Artillery Company.\n\nPrince Harry onstage at an Invictus Games event yesterday\n\nHe was said by sources to have had further sessions in the afternoon - including meeting business chief Sir Keith Mills, the former Invictus Games chairman - followed by a private dinner.\n\nIt has not been confirmed whether he came in on a scheduled, commercial flight, or flew by private jet from his home in California, or indeed where he is staying.\n\nHowever it is not believed to be in a royal residence. Harry has as no official home in the country after being asked to leave Frogmore, his and Meghan's Windsor home.\n\nHe is understood to have been staying in hotels or with friends during his occasional visits.\n\nAccording to reports, he plans to remain in the UK until tomorrow before flying to Nigeria where he will meet up with his wife for a quasi-royal tour, ostensibly to highlight the Invictus Games as well.\n\nHarry had not seen his father in person for 17 months before insisting he would fly to London in February after news of his cancer diagnosis was publicly announced.\n\nThe {"uri": "8117463597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:27:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:27:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:27:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://guardian.ng/news/prince-harry-in-london-but-not-meeting-king-charles/", "title": "Prince Harry in London, but not meeting King Charles", "body": "Prince Harry was in London Wednesday to mark the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games for wounded military veterans, but no meeting was scheduled with his estranged father King Charles III. As with all his trips to the UK since he moved to the United States in 2020, his three-day visit to the British capital...\n\nPrince Harry was in London Wednesday to mark the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games for wounded military veterans, but no meeting was scheduled with his estranged father King Charles III.\n\nAs with all his trips to the UK since he moved to the United States in 2020, his three-day visit to the British capital has sparked a fresh round of speculation about a reconciliation with his family.\n\nA possible end to four years of rancour and score-settling was seen as on the cards in February, when Harry jetted in from California to briefly see his father after it was announced that he had cancer.\n\nBut the palace doors look firmly shut to him this time round.\n\nA spokesman for the Duke of Sussex, as Harry is also known, said on Wednesday that a meeting this week \"will not be possible due His Majesty's full programme\".\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" he added.\n\nThe king's \"diary of commitments\" has been less full than usual in recent months, as Charles, 75, receives chemotherapy for cancer.\n\nBut it is filling up again after doctors said they were \"very encouraged\" by the progress of his treatment, allowing him to ease back into official public engagements.\n\nOn Tuesday, the king was pictured meeting Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka at Buckingham Palace, as Harry attended a discussion on the Invictus Games in London's financial district.\n\nOn Wednesday, the British head of state is expected to attend the first garden party of the year at Buckingham Palace and hold his weekly private audience with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.\n\nCommentators pointed out that Buckingham Palace is just under three miles (five kilometres) from the majestic dome of St Paul's, where Charles married Harry's mother, Princess Diana, in 1981.\n\nAs such, they interpreted the lack of meeting -- even for a short time -- as a snub, compounded by an announcement that Charles will appoint his elder son and heir Prince William as colonel-in-chief of Harry's old regiment.\n\nFormer army captain Harry served as a helicopter pilot with the Army Air Corps in Afghanistan, where he later described eliminating targets as like removing \"chess pieces\" from a board.\n\nNo meeting with William is planned either. He is due on a visit to Cornwall in southwest England, and the Isles of Scilly on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWilliam's wife Catherine is also undergoing cancer treatment and has not made any public appearance since December last year.\n\nThe brothers, once close, are reportedly no longer on speaking terms due to Harry's criticisms of royal life in a succession of high-profile interviews, TV documentaries and his autobiography.\n\nAfter Harry's three-day visit, he is due to join Meghan on a trip to Nigeria.\n\nHarry, 39, was characterised by the British media as a \"party prince\", who had none of the responsibilities of William, 41, who will become king after Charles.\n\nBut since marrying Meghan, an American former television actress, and quitting royal life, he has faced a sustained backlash in the UK, led by the tabloid press.\n\nFormer Daily Mirror editor and CNN host Piers Morgan, one of the most vocal critics of the couple, said Charles had given \"a big regal
